I will take scrupulous notes and write a book all about hemp paper making.
Natureflections greeting cards feature nature's healing beauty. They are blank inside and can be used for any occasion. They are wonderful to send to family and friends for birthdays, anniversaries, weddings, valentine's Mothers Day, Father's Day and every day, or to frame and hang on a wall or prop on an altar. The healing colors and vibrations of nature is a great way to lift anyone's spirits. The images are inspirational and a reminder that life is beautiful. Original limited edition print will feature a surprise image related to cannabis and will be printed with a hand-press, a beautiful old-school technique. 
If I don't reach my entire goal, I will use the funds only for certain hemp fibers and use studio time for only a few types of fiber-  first, hemp hurds, second, chopped fibers, and then textile scraps. and not invest in new molds/deckles, felts, or card printing and use cards that are already in stock to fulfill orders. (New molds and deckles will help make higher quality paper and various sizes and shapes.)
If over $10k is raised, I will make even more hemp paper! The goal is to do this full time. If more than $50k is raised, I will begin building a hemp paper making studio. Right now, I rent and have to work around studio hours, classes, and other renters.  I would love to work all day and night. Also, the beater and equipment is shared and used for various fibers- many other artists use dyes and fixers too, which sometimes rub off on my paper, making it difficult to produce purely natural paper. I also intend to experiment with natural plant dyes to make colored paper. Also will invest in automatic production by procuring or building a fourdrinier type belt style machine to be able to produce larger quantities of paper that are of consistent quality.
The Impact
As America prepares for the reincarnation of its hemp industry, we need to setup hemp fiber processing facilities. I believe that researching and working with hemp on a small scale will prove invaluable when it is time to establish large scale hemp paper production.
Hemp is much better for the environment than tree paper - Hemp cleans the air, earth, and water as it grows. It can be recycled 7-8 times and is archival!
Hemp does not require toxic chemicals for pulping, unlike timber which uses dioxins to remove lignins for pulping (which is a reason why the paper industry is one of the largest causes of water pollution on the planet.)
Hemp can be grown for seed and the stalk made into paper - a very efficient way to utilize precious farmland. Hemp also does not require much water and can grow very easily.
There are so many reasons to support hemp!
We are all connected - All One! Let's work together to heal the planet and create a sustainable new Earth for future generations.
Other Ways You Can Help
Like and share on Facebook, Twitter, Youtube, Google + and More!
Get the word out however you can.
Love and Gratitude!

story:
Exit Strategy

We are the exiting class of artists at University of Georgia in the Painting and Drawing department for spring 2014. We are hoping to raise funds to help put on a final exhibition event for the graduating students. Putting on an exhibition is expensive and any donation will be greatly appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

Our exhibition is fittingly going to be titled "Exit Strategy." It will be featuring multiple works from each of the 16 graduating students in the Painting/Drawing department and will serve as a final culmination of the years we have spent at the Lamar Dodd School of Art. We are trying to raise at least 500 dollars in order to help offset the cost of putting on what he hope to be a great exhibition. This includes things such as printing posters and cards for publicity, installation and de-installation of the show, and hosting a reception for the opening night of the exhibition.

Donors have the option to claim various prizes as appreciation for their donations.

Prizes are as follows:

$1 -     A huge thanks from all of us for helping us fund our show!

$5 -     A postcard from the exhibition and our huge thanks.

$10 -   Receive a poster and a postcard from the exhibition plus our undying thanks.

$25 -   Receive everything above plus a signed print from one of our graduating students.

$150 - Receive the postcard and the poster AND a one of a kind small artwork from a small selection of our graduating students. This of course also includes the undying thanks!

We will be sending out an email the day after the completion of the fundraising event at 12 p.m. EST to those who opted into the sketch and artwork perks. Contained will be a numbered preview of the available works. Please respond as soon as possible with the number of the work you wish to receive to claim your work. We will send updated lists as works are claimed.

The Impact

All Donations are appreciated and will help us to put on a really great show!

If you can't make a donation but still feel like helping please feel free to spread the word.

Thanks for reading!

story:
Chamber Art Summary

My name is Liviu Muntean, I live in Iasi, Romania, a place worth visiting, full of history, culture and natural beauty. I like to invite you to an unforgettable adventure tour! 

I am active as a lyrical artist, singer, at the Philharmonic “Moldova” in Iasi.
Click to view the choir!

Besides music, I am passionate with unstoppable joy to imagine things differently, to give them a new meaning, a new form,  a new destination! I take furniture that people don’t want anymore, restore it and try to make it a living entity. 



I have 5 nieces and 4 nephews, who I enjoy teaching to discover and create nice things.  

The reason of my campaign: the development of my small existing workshop which includes the renovation of the space and start of a workshop class for children where they will learn and aquire skills.

Through this we collect old things and make them new entities, we care about environment, and children will get a new perspective about work and life. Also, we will create new wooden things, such as toys and new garden and home small furniture pieces.

Your contribution to this project will be highly appreciated. 

What We Need

We have some tools and a space; we need to:

  • Redesign and renovate the space for our workshop and teaching class area ($1000);
  • Complete our tool list with wood working tools ($600);
  • Buy a small wood lathe ($1300).
  • If I don’t reach the entire goal, the funds will cover one of the above objectives, and we will complete later the other tasks by our own funds or from other sources.

What You Get

I express my gratitude and thanks to all. The pledges I am offering you include objects refurbished and other things and services that you will love, I hope! Also, with your accept, your name/brand/link will be published on the following page: Chamber Art Partners

Cammber Art Card
- Everyone will get a nice card online with the new workshop and pictures with children working there!

Wood Working Manual
- Step-by-step wood working manual (in PDF format) for refurbishing small furniture.

Wooden Toys Plans
- Step-by-step wood working plans for creating wooden toys.

Unique small furniture
- Unique small furniture vintage and refurbished objects; each piece is an original design from a carefully selected pool of furniture makers.

Chamber Art Violin


Chamber Art Table


Black Swan Table


Bed – The Night Desire


Visits to wonderful Romanian landscapes
- Visits to the shop and to wonderful Romanian landscapes and monasteries, etc. (see also perks column on right sidebar).
Details about great places to visit in Romania: click here!

The Impact

The project will contribute to save the environment buy collecting and refurbishing the old furniture, reducing landfill waste, create new skills to children and, on long-term, create new local jobs.

Children who will benefit from this working class are my nephews and nieces, their coleagues, children from foster care families and many others. They will learn to redesign old small furniture pieces, books, antiques and other things, and to create new toys and diferent fine objects. I enjoy being their teacher in the weekends!

Toys created by children will be sold and/or given to foster families who care about abandoned kids. The funds from any item sold are used to develop our project and, in the future, to transform it in a social or business entreprise. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have friends online, you might want to spread the word about my project; below you'll find more info about me and my work. 

About me: http://www.chamberart.me/about-me 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/mychamberart 

Also you may want to use the Indiegogo share tools. Thank you very much! 
Liviu

story:
I am a working artist named Jen Berry. I believe connectivity with other people is a vital part of being human, it can offer encouragement when things are dark. My mission is to fight depression and isolation by providing art as a restoration of faith.

Ten years ago, I began sending artwork through the mail, free of charge, to anyone who provided a street address. I have sent over 1500 pieces of art through the mail, to date. On occasion, I stand on corners, waving to commuting motorists and bikers, greeting them, and giving out art to cheer their day.

Currently, there are over 500 requests to receive free art. Many in my community have donated time and materials to this project and I am very thankful for that support. However, the number of requests continues to grow and is exceeding my current ability to fulfill in a timely fashion. In order to continue this practice on what has become a large scale, I need to obtain an Oregon business license for Jen Berry Artitude in order take advantage of opportunities to better support this project, business cards, promotional stickers, paper and printer ink.


All donors receive my eternal love and gratitude; I would not be here today without them. Smaller donations can expect to receive, a personal thank you card. Mid-level donations will receive a thank you card and the first run of a limited edition Artitude sticker. Larger donations will be sent a personal thank you card, an Artitude sticker and a special, one-of-a-kind original piece of art. If the goal is not met, all funds received will first be put toward materials necessary in order to print thank you cards for those who have donated supporting my mission.

Gifting art shows us all we are not alone in this world, human connection can soothe solitude, bring hope and reduce fear of the unknown. I believe action bearing love can change the world, I believe it can bring light to the dark corners.

If you’d like to help without donation, please share this link. Please visit my Facebook page Ginberry Artitude to see current updates on what is happening in the world of freeing art and giving hope.

story:
An iconic, re-purposed 1940s-era dairy barn has, for almost 20 years, been the magnet drawing together diverse artisans from all backgrounds, skill levels, and mediums. The Jacksonville Center for the Arts (verified 501-c-3 nonprofit) in Floyd County, Virginia (The Jax) has studio and exhibition space that is in demand every day of the year. The Jax will soon take its place among the longest-running rural arts centers in the Commonwealth of Virginia.

Older craftspeople come to sew a communal quilt. An amateur potter rents studio space to transition to self-employment as proprietor of an artisan business. A professional artist boosts his income stream by teaching a class in our working studios. A musician hands down skills and passion to the next generation. Students from the local elementary school dream and create with us (and stay safe) after school and before their parents come home from work.

We’re in a beautiful but remote area of Virginia, a few miles from the Blue Ridge Parkway. There’s no interstate. No railroad. No major industry. But we have plenty of entrepreneurs: organic farmers and potters; painters and jewelry makers; dancers and blacksmiths. These are the folks who are the engine of our region’s creative economy. The Jax is their catalyst.

Our Community's Values:

Even though our county’s population is growing, and even though we attract cultural consumers, there is a lot of competition for nonprofit dollars. This is why we are reaching out to you.

In our old barn, we’re bursting at the seams and limping along with inefficient exhibition climate control, and stage lighting systems. We need to do more for our community through vibrant online publications and exciting web-accessed tutorials, interior upgrades and space expansions, and superior staff.

During the old barn’s 20 years as a rural arts center, we have:

  • graduated 15 successful, surviving creative small businesses from our incubator for startup cultural businesses
  • welcomed an average of 10K visitors/year to our free exhibitions & tenant studios
  • boosted the income opportunities of ~2500 professional artisans
  • designed, offered, and managed 650 art and craft classes for adults
  • engaged 4,500 adult lifelong learners and aspiring professional artists in hands-on, experiential education
  • ignited the imaginations of an average of 1000 K-12 children ANNUALLY
  • employed, trained, and re-trained 30 individuals: 10 young adults starting their work lives; 15 older adults considered underskilled by the private sector; and 5 transitioning new residents
  • engaged 20K volunteers to smooth operations and boost staff effectiveness, who have given a total average of 10K hours PER YEAR to The Jax
  • hosted thousands of meetings, gatherings, workshops, special events, festivals & small conferences
  • held 250 art exhibitions and corresponding Meet the Artists receptions

It is time to take The Jax to the next level. Our diverse users want the same things we do: imaginative ways and fun opportunities to access art, music, craft, and inspiration. The better our equipment, facilities, and personnel, the more we can include underserved people. We have done major work with several granting agencies to fund upcoming infrastructure improvements (a new education/multipurpose room; paved parking/driveway; improved ceramics studio). With your help, we will additionally acquire the necessary means to remain a truly community-oriented, egalitarian arts center in rural America, at both the concrete and virtual levels. With additional digital and realtime tools and equipment, as well as the space and talent to use them, we will evolve, broaden, and extend our services.

Working in the old barn, last renovated in 2003, we lack basic resources. Our main gallery's environmental control and lighting systems are inefficient. We have outgrown our storage, administrative, and classroom spaces. We need a professional lighting system for our smaller performance venue; and a sound-proof audio/video work room (and upgraded equipment) to boost our marketing outreach. 

Finally, if we could “seed” the beginning of an endowment so we can build an investment in the future, the annual wintertime downturn in our programming cycle will not wreak its typical “doomsday” impact on our cash flow.

Here’s what we need:

  • $20,000 digital education studio
  • $5,000 staff training for digital studio management & ops
  • $15,000 stage & exhibit lighting & climate control systems
  • $10,000 minimum for the foundation of an endowment

We expect to leverage your support as private match investment: a requirement to qualify for public (state and federal) grant funding. This means every dollar you invest in this campaign offers a potential doubling effect, through upcoming and pending grant applications.

Still, one of the most effective ways you can help is by simply spreading the word about rural Floyd’s Jax. Tell your friends that you’ve discovered us on Indiegogo! Tweet about us using #Jaxagogo. Remember: Sharing is Sexy!

Copy and send our Indie campaign link (shortlink = igg.me/at/FloydVAJax) to your friends!

Our twitter handle: jax_art Use our hashtag #jaxagogo

Find us on Facebook, too!

Your donation will mean The Jax can strengthen the connections between makers and buyers; teachers and students; visitors and unique opportunities; children and art. 

Our public school elementary school children currently get only 1 hour of art in school per month. As we speak, Floyd’s public school representatives are trying to work with a $100K budget cut. What they’re considering is eliminating our last two public school art teachers’ jobs. With your help, we will have space for an expanded after-school program that makes a difference in our children’s lives (and the lives of their working parents, with no “home alone” scenario). 

Floyd is not populous enough to have a middle school—so our eighth graders attend Floyd County High School, and receive ZERO art instruction during their first year in the building. Creative education opportunities for youth = a critical component of the future and survival of Rural America's communities.

In exchange for your help, if you choose one of our perks, you will receive regional handmade art, craft, iconic Floyd-only items, or an opportunity for a unique escape to funky Floyd. All perks have been donated to us by supporters, artisans, businesses, advocates, and members. (We have a roll call of participating artists & businesses and their bios/contacts on our website. Check out Jaxagogo Friends – don't miss knowing more about the hands that made each item!)

These stakeholders invest in The Jax through giving of their time, talent, and treasure every day. But many are “starving artists.” Investing in our campaign is a straight-line, direct way to support the hands that “make” Appalachia.

Even though there are many unique "one-only" perk items, we have a deep bench of one-only replacements in most investment categories. Come back often to see what has been taken, and what has been made available to say "thank you" to investors at each level. So many artisans have joined us to offer their talent and inspiration to you in return for helping us! Visit often and see what's next!

We are proud to be among the catalysts for Floyd’s creative economy, and wish to expand that reputation and influence across a wider span of geography. Be a part of our growth and expand WITH us! Your contribution will be an investment in a piece of Rural America’s future.

Whether you choose to invest or not, one of the most effective ways you can help is by simply spreading the word about The Jax.

Our Website

Our Facebook page

Our Twitter handle

#jaxagogo!

Thanks for your support! We can’t do it without you.

Comments? Suggestions? Questions? email*  lee@jacksonville_center.org
(*please be sure to remove the underline _ in the email address above before hitting "send" - thanks!)

story:
Hello, everyone. This campaign (or fundraiser) is to help raise money for the art department at Shasta College. Thank you all so much for coming by and supporting this page! If you cannot donate, sharing this is the next best thing. Again, thank you so much!


- Alicia Mello

story:
Hello, we are creating an other-wordly art installation that fills a field with 500 enigmatic self-illuminated reeds. The field will come to life in light breezes, swaying dynamically, revealing the invisible wind patterns that whisper across them. In stronger winds, it will chaotically visualise gusts and squalls, making the invisible visible.

We'd like to install this large scale artwork at Nowhere 2015 and attempt to exhibit it around Europe until Nowhere 2016.


In 2012 Pete Johnson created an installation called The Shipping Forecast in response to the the high winds which are a common feature of the Nowhere site. The work consisted of 50 x 1.8 metre fibreglass stems with bright green LED spherical diffusers at the top.  It resembled a field of unearthly reeds which would stand serene and statuesque in still weather, sway gently in light breeze and sweep through wide, chaotic arcs in strong gales. 

 

                                      


Over the next couple of years the piece was expanded to 120 stems covering an area of approximately 480 sq metres in 2014.

For 2015 we will rebuild the installation with 500 stems, increase the height to 2.5 metres and add tech which will enable the spheres to glow green in still weather and become increasingly blue as the wind speed increases. This iteration will fill an area of 2000 sq metres and, hopefully, reveal wave formations resembling those found in large windblown grasslands. Spacially it will be the largest Nowhere art project to date.

We estimate the total cost to be in the region of £3000. Nowhere Art has granted €700 (£515) towards the cost and we're now seeking £1000 to help realise this. 


What it is and what it costs.

Expansion of the existing piece won't work. The extra weight of the electronic components is too great for the 4mm rods and thus necessitates a complete new build with 6mm rods.

The tech for the motion sensitive blue green fade has been designed by Aran Dasan and will cost around £900

1500 metres of 6mm fibreglass rod has been purchased at a cost of £800.

Miscellaneous materials such as zip ties, silicon sealant, heat shrink, soldering materials, grid measuring/marking and a level hole punching system for the ground. erm...£150?

Diffusers - £50 - £200 depending chosen system.

For the diffusers we may move away from ping pong balls to white plastic toothbrush holders as they they tend to resemble bullrushes. There's also the option to use recycle PET bottles to create something like this:


A 10% contingency is built into the budget to accommodate a degree of anticipated manufacturing error and damage or loss of stems on site.
If the fund goal isn't reached it'll be self financed. We undertake to complete the project whatever happens.

Initial test run assembly of  5 PCB's

Why is it bigger?

Scale is a significant factor in the ability of the piece to function as planned. The existing stucture appears to move as a chaotic whole when the wind hits it because it's too small to register fluctuations in wind speed and direction. The 400% scale increase combined with the blue green wind speed sensor system will present, at least,  a beautiful spectacle and, hopefully, an impressive revelation of the Monegros wind patterns.


Who we are.

Pete Johnson

a meandering polymath recently liberated from the constraints of corporate motion graphics. First attended BM in 2001, is a founder member of London Decom and Nowhere and has since been heavily involved in related creative endeavours including:

  • Build and installation of successful tests for this project at Nowhere since 2012.
  • Creative and operational management of the NFS Gladys project.
  • Nowhere Omnibus - concept, pre-production, installation and on site project management at BM 2012.
  • Central co-ordination, build lead and site management, Nowhere 2004-2007
  • London Decom 2002 - 2010

His ability to electronically evaporate half an inch from the ends of 3 screwdrivers has led him to grasp the guiding hand of young whizz kid...

Aran Dasan 

a London-based designer and engineer. He currently co-leads the second year of the the Innovation Design Engineering double-masters course, at the Royal College of Art and Imperial College London, whilst freelancing for various London-based startups.

A large amount of Aran's experience is in developing electronics for sustainability-related applications (waterless toilets, smart thermostats for social housing, bycatch-reducing industrial fishing gear) - a lot of knowledge that has been applied in developing the lights for this Nowhere project.
Aran has been going to Nowhere since 2006 and, after a 3 year break from the event, he's looking forward to returning with Pete and the Shipping Forecast!

Risks & Challenges

We're trying to avoid this kind of stress. There's a bit of unknown territory involved in assembling circuits at this scale in these numbers and we'll run volunteer workshops to try and keep costs down.  It's a bit of a first for us.

STOP PRESS!...

Last week we made the difficult decision to employ an automation facility. The tiny accelerometer was taking too long to accurately position, we had 400 left to assemble and the schedule was getting seriously out of synch. This has added around £1200 to the total budget. This is included in the above, revised, budget of £3000.  We extra need your help now!
Because of this and a few other unexpected glitches we've launched the campaign later than planned. The campaign will end after Nowhere.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate please help publicise the campaign:
  • Tell friends, colleagues and anyone who's interested to have a look.
  • Share this link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and your Blog.
  • Email people directly who you think would be interested in supporting us.

We're working so hard that we don't have time to organise perks. If anyone fancies organising some schwag to encourage donations please get in touch.

We have arranged two weekends of assembly in London on 20th-21st and 27th-28th of June. If anyone would like to help and learn a few tricks, let us know.


THANKS!

story:
Kearny Street Workshop’s (KSW) APAture returns October 2nd through October 17th, 2015, at select venues throughout San Francisco. In its fourteenth season, APAture presents and promotes the work of emerging Asian Pacific American (APA) talent in film, literary arts, music, performing arts, comics and illustration, and visual arts. This year, APAture 2015: Future Tense asks artists to look into their crystal balls and imagine what’s possible in the world of tomorrow and envision their communities in the future tense.

KSW invites you to help make this festival possible by making a donation today to help us raise our goal of $3,000 to support emerging artists that utilize APAture as a unique art space. Through this one-of-a-kind festival, we are able to provide a platform for APA artists to explore their work and share ideas with audiences from their local communities.  

This year, approximately 2,000 attendees representing the wonderfully diverse communities of the San Francisco Bay Area and beyond will attend APAture 2015: Future Tense to experience the work of dozens of local artists sharing their outlooks on the future. What’s more, APAture will highlight six featured artists (one representing each art discipline) who will introduce work-in-progress excerpts or new art pieces to event audiences throughout the festival.

APAture 2015 is a labor of love for KSW’s staff and APAture’s all-volunteer General Planning Committee (GPC), which is made up of a diverse mix of artists, educators, students, and young professionals. Drawing inspiration from KSW’s mission, the GPC works from the belief that we are the ones who have to create our own spaces for this work, because the artists who will take these stages during APAture 2015: Future Tense are the ones who are going to help shape and define what our art means for years to come.

The mission of KSW’s APAture is to present and promote art by local emerging artists of APA descent; to cultivate and strengthen the sense of community among our artists and audiences; and to raise awareness of the creativity and diversity within the APA arts community.

GOALS

  • Raise $3,000 to help underwrite the expenses related to producing APAture 2015: Future Tense. These expenses include: the artist honorarium awarded to each of the six featured artists, marketing and outreach, event venue rental, photo and video documentation of the APAture activities, coordinator fees, and production and wrap-up costs.

  • Provide creative spaces for emerging Asian Pacific American artists of multiple disciplines to help maintain the health and sustainability of arts engagement in our communities.

  • Build networks of support for emerging APA artists and audiences that are productive and lasting.

  • Provide a venue for the creative voices in our community to tell our stories and empower one another to take control of our own narratives.

SOME EXAMPLES OF WHAT YOUR DONATION WILL SUPPORT

$10: Underwrites the APAture application fee for one artist.

$100: Enables us to provide meals and travel assistance for our artists, staff, and volunteers.

$200: Helps underwrite the artist honorarium awarded to one of the festival’s featured artist who will present excerpts from new work or a piece that has not yet been presented to the public.

$500: Helps underwrite production and documentation costs, including venue and equipment rental, hiring technicians, photographers, etc.

$1,000: Helps underwrite the costs of hiring a coordinator to manage the APAture activities, coordinate the 16-person APAture volunteer general planning committee and selected artists, and organize all other aspects of the festival and helps underwrite the artist honorarium awarded to one of the festival’s featured artists.

Other ways to support APAture 2015: Future Tense:

  • Back this campaign and encourage your friends and contacts to also donate by Monday, September 9th

  • Like Kearny Street Workshop on Facebook

  • Follow Kearny Street Workshop on Twitter

  • Post this campaign to your social media with the hashtags #APAture2015 #futuretense

About Kearny Street Workshop: KSW is a non-profit organization dedicated to producing, presenting, and promoting art that empowers Asian and/or Pacific Islander communities. Since 1972, KSW has offered adult arts education programs and multidisciplinary arts presentations to local community members. Join us at kearnystreet.org.

Other ways to make a donation:

Make checks payable to Kearny Street Workshop and include APAture 2015 in the memo field and mail to:

Kearny Street Workshop

Attn: APAture 2015

P.O. Box 14545

San Francisco, CA 94114-0545

Kearny Street Workshop is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

Federal Tax ID: 94-3207003

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

For questions, contact:

Jason Bayani | Program Manager 

510-673-3727 | jason@kearnystreet.org

story:
Looking to sell 300 facial tissue dispensers.  Goal to acquire a laser cutter and/or laser cutting rental.


Description:  Recycled corrugated art.  Cardboard Zen facial tissue dispensers feature simple and beautiful corrugated grain.  Layered and built for tissue dispensing bliss.  

Measures: 6" tall x 6.5" wide.  Fits standard box size 5" x 5" tissue box contents (approximately 75 tissue count).  Arrives filled with approximately 75 tissue count.

Removable and engraved bottom seal for tissue refilling (twist and lift lock). 

Great for creative environments.

+++Note:  The three tissue dispensers above are dispensers, not covers.  Tissues need to be liberated from the point of purchase package and placed into the dispenser.  It's quick and easy... and a tiny habit hack that can lead to a more artful life.  

Description:  Recycled corrugated art cover.  Cardboard Zen facial tissue BOX cover, layered and built for tissue dispensing bliss.

Measures:  11" long x 7" wide x 4" high.  Fits standard 9" long x 5" wide x 3.5" high (approximately 120 tissue count box).  Arrives filled with 120 tissue count box.

Great for creative environments.

story:
RELAUNCH of this Indiegogo for my TRIP to see my SPLITS ART hanging in Paris:

https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/part-deux-l...


WHY AM I ON INDIEGOGO?

Hello! Bonjour! My name is...excuse moi, ah-hem...Je m'applle Erin Barylski, but most people know me as my nom de plume, SPLITS ART.  SPLITS ART is my unique style of painting, where I use my entire body as my paintbrush! After years of dedication to stretching canvases and my body, I have been invited to show my art, at the “Gustave Eiffel Hall” inside the Eiffel Tower, Paris, France during the international show “La Grande Exposition Universelle”.


I am honored to show you a clipping from the invitation: 

“Dear Erin,

I want to invite you to participate at the most prestigious art event in the world: Exposition at the Eiffel Tower.

The most important artists in the world will be invited to participate at "La Grande Exposition Universelle" to be held inside the Eiffel Tower, “Gustave Eiffel” Hall.

In one of the most visited monuments all over the world, after 125 years from the great universal exhibition of Paris, some artists of different nationalities, will be the protagonists of the event with their artworks. The great figurative masters will be placed side by side to those of informal and abstract art.

The Tour Eiffel, once again will receive new proofs of creativity, visual stories of artists intended to go down in history.”      


!!!WOW!!!  That is some pretty amazing recognition, right?!

My dream is coming true to go down in Art History!  Considering it is the 21st century, doing something that is uniquely new was not an easy feat...but it is in my soul to expand upon the creative limitless possibilities in my performance art creations of SPLITS ART.  Growing up, even finger painting wasn’t vast nor freeing enough, especially with a smock on; now, I create larger than life artwork using only my limber body as my paintbrush. In efforts to keep this momentum going and having my BIG ARTISTIC BREAK, I am stretching out and asking for your support and financial help!  But first, let me take a moment to tell you a little more about SPLITS ART...


WHAT EXACTLY IS SPLITS ART?

My performance art, I have been told, is something you have to see to believe!  I use my flexible paint covered physique as a paintbrush, while performing choreographed and/or improvised dance, yoga, and contortion upon a canvas to entertain and create vibrant 2D artworks. 

My high energy talents and unique performance style have landed me on America’s Got Talent, The Late Show with David Letterman and at the world renown Art Basel in Miami, Florida 2013, and 2011.  I was most recently awarded Miami’s Best Performing Artist 2013 by RAWartists; was the headlining entertainer, with a full gallery show, at A Splash of Style, during the prestigious Miami Swimwear Week 2014; and I was the main entertainment at YELP’s 10 year Anniversary Party in Miami, 2014! 

My large scale artworks average 5ft x 10ft and have a variety of styles ranging from contemporary, impressionistic, logo’s and precise imagery; many performances are created at lightning fast speeds of 15-30 minutes and my more intricate pieces take hours!


WHY AM I ASKING FOR HELP?

ANSWER 1 (too legit):

I’M A STARVING ARTIST, THAT’S WHY!!!  I’ve literally watched money go down the drain over the years, as I have showered off countless gallons of paint residue after my many performances!  

***side note:  I use non-toxic children’s washable tempera paint and spend extra for biodegradable plastic #GoGreen!***  

PLUS, I am 100% ready for my true potential of success to be here. I'm exhausted of praying to make it to my next paycheck from my 9 to 5,  in order to pay my bills and hopefully have enough money left to buy MORE paint… God forbid, I ever have  to use mustard AGAIN because I ran out of yellow paint( yes, true story, I smelled like a hotdog, it was awful).   S'il vous plait, do NOT pass the Grey Poupon.


ANSWER 2 (the open heart):  

Reminiscing over the past year I have been blessed with many wonderful opportunities to perform and show my art at some truly amazing events.  I am thankful for all the support I have received, the people I have met, connected with, inspired, and made smile.  I am forever grateful to those who have purchased my SPLITS ART paintings and prints and those who visualize doing so one day. I have been performing out of my own pocket because SPLITS ART is what I believe in and am passionate about! Do what you love and you’ll never work a day in your life!

ANSWER 3 (my dream is nearly my reality):  

I am teetering at that BIG BREAK point!  I know in my colorful heart of hearts that what I do is so very special and I am deserving of reaching my BHAG (Big Hairy Audacious Goal) where my artwork is selling next to the masters for its true value of six figures and beyond!  I see myself making my art a profitable career and creating a legacy; I have so many vibrant ideas to share with the world!   

ANSWER 4 (the big picture):

Those of you who have been a part of and/or watched my journey over the years have seen the growth, transformation and dedication to my body of work, I wouldn’t be here without you!  I THANK YOU with all my heart!  I desperately would love to not only repay you, but someday soon I intend to hire all my talented friends who have lent me their time, kindness and gifts of many forms because they see what I see in SPLITS ART.  I dream of a winning future with my SPLITS ART TEAM by my side!  

To those of you who are new SPLITS ART fans or just reading about me for the first time….First and most importantly, THANK YOU for spending your time on my page.  Second, I ask you, try to imagine what I have invested in time, effort and cost into each 5ft by 10ft painting (AND of course, my practice paintings!!!  It is NOT easy to choreograph and none the less figure out how to paint a ginormous bumblebee, landing on a flower, in only 15 minutes, when you are upside down half the time, and the other half spinning around, trying to look cute and keep on smiling!). 

Luckily, you don't have to imagine because here is the non-exaggerated answer: it has been thousands upon thousands of self-invested dollars and years upon years to have reached this point in my artistic career.  I am beyond excited to have this opportunity to share my art internationally and continue to inspire others to think outside of the coloring book lines of life.  

   

HOW MUCH HELP DO I NEED?

Financially I’m would like to manifest $15,000 USD for this Parisian experience.  Each artwork submission at this exclusive event is €1.800,00 rounding to nearly $2,500.00 per painting (there is a price break for the more paintings you send, apx $6700 for 3 paintings).  My paintings will be greatly cropped to fit within the exhibit requirements.  Ideally, I would like to have 3 pieces on display so it will appear as a triptych of a single artwork of my 'normal' proportions.  

In addition, I will need to cover the cost of my shipping/insurance on my artwork to and from Paris (likely the canvas will be shipped rolled-up to cut down on costs), reframing of the artwork in Paris, flight (apx $1200-1500), hotel stay (granted I will try to find someone to host my stay or budget it out in a hostel, but at max $200/night for 7-9 nights apx $1500 - $2000 ), local travel needs, a lesson or duex to brush up on my high school level 1 francais, and additional expenses such as shipping my SPLITS ART performance supplies for a TBD performance wink, wink, wink.   

Since the Gustave Eiffel Hall is so prestigious I will not be permitted to have a performance within the Eiffle Tower.  Yet, I will surely bend over backwards to find somewhere that will host a SPLITS ART performance.  It is a possibility to do an impromptu painting near the Eiffel Tower or more likely in front of the Louvre (as the following day after the show is the Salon Art Shopping 2014, au Carrousel de Louve Musee, talk about perfect timing!)!  I would love to give the metallic miming robots a little friendly street performance competition!  


OTHER FORMS OF HELP…

A positive thought or intention for SPLITS ART (heck, think of one for yourself too while you are at it)!  Please send some good energy my way (and I'll send some right back to you!) and envision me selling my art for big euros!  

The human connection is the biggest way to share!  Please talk about my story and share the links via your email and social media outlets.  It is a small world out there and I know with your help we can get the word out.  Please help me find people to pitch in and I will be able to be part of this exhibit!  This is truly an experience of a lifetime to be able to show my artwork inside the Eiffel Tower!


WHAT IF I DON’T MAKE MY GOAL? (geeeze Debbie Downer!  Take a hike!)

Your donation will still be going to a great cause!  I will send my art, at minimum, one piece, even if I can’t send myself to Paris.  Getting my name out there in this international show is a true honor!  

POSITIVE POLLY SAYS WITH A SMILE: Anything in-between 2 or 3 paintings or (dreaming bigger!) even above my goal (fingers, arms, legs and toes crossed) it will go to purchasing paint, canvas, supplies and the ‘likewise’ to continue future SPLITS ART performances...and yes, of course you are invited!  


BUT WAIT!  THERE’S MORE THAN JUST A GOOD DOES OF KARMA!:  Check out the right hand side of the page... you get a little special something with each level of donation. Plus my ever-enduring gratitude and knowing that there is a smile on my face and likely a smudge of paint on my chin or nose too! 

*** Please pay via PayPal if possible (*see fine print below) 


IN CLOSING with LOVE, LIGHT and PAINT: 

“All children are artists. The problem is how to remain an artist once he grows up.” - Pablo Picasso

Always Smiling,

Erin "SPLITS ART" Barylski


SPECIAL THANKS: 

My ever-supportive parents Joanne and Brian who couldn't be prouder of their little girl, Loft 954 Studios - you have always given me the space and time I needed to grow SPLITS ART, Chris "Headshots" Hedlund, Josh Ott Photo and Design, RAWartists.org, MadFlower Creative Group, LMNT Gallery, Nina Torres Fine Art Gallery, TSL Lounge, The Stage, Carousel Gallery, Miaimee Makeup, The Beach Channel, ECOMB, Yelp Miami and The Coral Gables Museum, Koncept Events, my 9-5 job Weatherby Healthcare (for allowing me the time off to follow my BHAG!), PS Yoga Studio, Barkan Method Yoga Studio, The New Times, The Pride Center, The Late Show with David Letterman, America's Got Talent, Home Depot, JoAnn Fabrics, Pearl Arts and Crafts Store, Wix.com, my amazing family, my awesome friends and all my super SPLITS ART FANS!!  I love you all!


THE FINE PRINT:

*Please pay via PayPal if possible!   My first payment for this event due on September 5, 2014 and I need your help to make this happen.  Paying via PayPal puts the money directly into my account, for instant access.  

*If you pay via credit card, I am still very grateful, but I will not receive the money until 15 days after my campaign ends.  This will make it extremely difficult for me to make my 2nd payment which is due on September 25th, 2014.

*Indiegogo's fees:  When I make my goal, Indiegogo, will deduct 4%, at $15,000 that would be -$600's in fees.  Campaigns that do not make their goal will be deducted 9% of the donations acquired (for me that would be at max apx $1200 in fees).

*Please let me know if you have any questions by emailing me at splitsart@gmail.com or visit my website www.splitsart.com MERCI BEAUCOUP!!!
story_txt:
RELAUNCH of this Indiegogo for my TRIP to see my SPLITS ART hanging in Paris:https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/part-deux-l...WHY AM I ON INDIEGOGO?

Hello! Bonjour! My name is...excuse moi, ah-hem...Je m'applle Erin Barylski, but most people know me as my nom de plume, SPLITS ART.  SPLITS ART is my unique style of painting, where I use my entire body as my paintbrush! After years of dedication to stretching canvases and my body, I have been invited to show my art, at the “Gustave Eiffel Hall” inside the Eiffel Tower, Paris, France during the international show “La Grande Exposition Universelle”.

I am honored to show you a clipping from the invitation: 

“Dear Erin,

I want to invite you to participate at the most prestigious art event in the world: Exposition at the Eiffel Tower.

The most important artists in the world will be invited to participate at "La Grande Exposition Universelle" to be held inside the Eiffel Tower, “Gustave Eiffel” Hall.

In one of the most visited monuments all over the world, after 125 years from the great universal exhibition of Paris, some artists of different nationalities, will be the protagonists of the event with their artworks. The great figurative masters will be placed side by side to those of informal and abstract art.

The Tour Eiffel, once again will receive new proofs of creativity, visual stories of artists intended to go down in history.”      


!!!WOW!!!  That is some pretty amazing recognition, right?!

My dream is coming true to go down in Art History!  Considering it is the 21st century, doing something that is uniquely new was not an easy feat...but it is in my soul to expand upon the creative limitless possibilities in my performance art creations of SPLITS ART.  Growing up, even finger painting wasn’t vast nor freeing enough, especially with a smock on; now, I create larger than life artwork using only my limber body as my paintbrush. In efforts to keep this momentum going and having my BIG ARTISTIC BREAK, I am stretching out and asking for your support and financial help!  But first, let me take a moment to tell you a little more about SPLITS ART...


WHAT EXACTLY IS SPLITS ART?

My performance art, I have been told, is something you have to see to believe!  I use my flexible paint covered physique as a paintbrush, while performing choreographed and/or improvised dance, yoga, and contortion upon a canvas to entertain and create vibrant 2D artworks. My high energy talents and unique performance style have landed me on America’s Got Talent, The Late Show with David Letterman and at the world renown Art Basel in Miami, Florida 2013, and 2011.  I was most recently awarded Miami’s Best Performing Artist 2013 by RAWartists; was the headlining entertainer, with a full gallery show, at A Splash of Style, during the prestigious Miami Swimwear Week 2014; and I was the main entertainment at YELP’s 10 year Anniversary Party in Miami, 2014! My large scale artworks average 5ft x 10ft and have a variety of styles ranging from contemporary, impressionistic, logo’s and precise imagery; many performances are created at lightning fast speeds of 15-30 minutes and my more intricate pieces take hours!


WHY AM I ASKING FOR HELP?

ANSWER 1 (too legit):
I’M A STARVING ARTIST, THAT’S WHY!!!  I’ve literally watched money go down the drain over the years, as I have showered off countless gallons of paint residue after my many performances!  ***side note:  I use non-toxic children’s washable tempera paint and spend extra for biodegradable plastic #GoGreen!***  PLUS, I am 100% ready for my true potential of success to be here. I'm exhausted of praying to make it to my next paycheck from my 9 to 5,  in order to pay my bills and hopefully have enough money left to buy MORE paint… God forbid, I ever have  to use mustard AGAIN because I ran out of yellow paint( yes, true story, I smelled like a hotdog, it was awful).   S'il vous plait, do NOT pass the Grey Poupon.

ANSWER 2 (the open heart):  
Reminiscing over the past year I have been blessed with many wonderful opportunities to perform and show my art at some truly amazing events.  I am thankful for all the support I have received, the people I have met, connected with, inspired, and made smile.  I am forever grateful to those who have purchased my SPLITS ART paintings and prints and those who visualize doing so one day. I have been performing out of my own pocket because SPLITS ART is what I believe in and am passionate about! Do what you love and you’ll never work a day in your life!

ANSWER 3 (my dream is nearly my reality):  
I am teetering at that BIG BREAK point!  I know in my colorful heart of hearts that what I do is so very special and I am deserving of reaching my BHAG (Big Hairy Audacious Goal) where my artwork is selling next to the masters for its true value of six figures and beyond!  I see myself making my art a profitable career and creating a legacy; I have so many vibrant ideas to share with the world!   

ANSWER 4 (the big picture):
Those of you who have been a part of and/or watched my journey over the years have seen the growth, transformation and dedication to my body of work, I wouldn’t be here without you!  I THANK YOU with all my heart!  I desperately would love to not only repay you, but someday soon I intend to hire all my talented friends who have lent me their time, kindness and gifts of many forms because they see what I see in SPLITS ART.  I dream of a winning future with my SPLITS ART TEAM by my side!  
To those of you who are new SPLITS ART fans or just reading about me for the first time….First and most importantly, THANK YOU for spending your time on my page.  Second, I ask you, try to imagine what I have invested in time, effort and cost into each 5ft by 10ft painting (AND of course, my practice paintings!!!  It is NOT easy to choreograph and none the less figure out how to paint a ginormous bumblebee, landing on a flower, in only 15 minutes, when you are upside down half the time, and the other half spinning around, trying to look cute and keep on smiling!). 
Luckily, you don't have to imagine because here is the non-exaggerated answer: it has been thousands upon thousands of self-invested dollars and years upon years to have reached this point in my artistic career.  I am beyond excited to have this opportunity to share my art internationally and continue to inspire others to think outside of the coloring book lines of life.  

    
HOW MUCH HELP DO I NEED?

Financially I’m would like to manifest $15,000 USD for this Parisian experience.  Each artwork submission at this exclusive event is €1.800,00 rounding to nearly $2,500.00 per painting (there is a price break for the more paintings you send, apx $6700 for 3 paintings).  My paintings will be greatly cropped to fit within the exhibit requirements.  Ideally, I would like to have 3 pieces on display so it will appear as a triptych of a single artwork of my 'normal' proportions.  In addition, I will need to cover the cost of my shipping/insurance on my artwork to and from Paris (likely the canvas will be shipped rolled-up to cut down on costs), reframing of the artwork in Paris, flight (apx $1200-1500), hotel stay (granted I will try to find someone to host my stay or budget it out in a hostel, but at max $200/night for 7-9 nights apx $1500 - $2000 ), local travel needs, a lesson or duex to brush up on my high school level 1 francais, and additional expenses such as shipping my SPLITS ART performance supplies for a TBD performance wink, wink, wink.   

Since the Gustave Eiffel Hall is so prestigious I will not be permitted to have a performance within the Eiffle Tower.  Yet, I will surely bend over backwards to find somewhere that will host a SPLITS ART performance.  It is a possibility to do an impromptu painting near the Eiffel Tower or more likely in front of the Louvre (as the following day after the show is the Salon Art Shopping 2014, au Carrousel de Louve Musee, talk about perfect timing!)!  I would love to give the metallic miming robots a little friendly street performance competition!  

OTHER FORMS OF HELP…

A positive thought or intention for SPLITS ART (heck, think of one for yourself too while you are at it)!  Please send some good energy my way (and I'll send some right back to you!) and envision me selling my art for big euros!  

The human connection is the biggest way to share!  Please talk about my story and share the links via your email and social media outlets.  It is a small world out there and I know with your help we can get the word out.  Please help me find people to pitch in and I will be able to be part of this exhibit!  This is truly an experience of a lifetime to be able to show my artwork inside the Eiffel Tower!


WHAT IF I DON’T MAKE MY GOAL? (geeeze Debbie Downer!  Take a hike!)

Your donation will still be going to a great cause!  I will send my art, at minimum, one piece, even if I can’t send myself to Paris.  Getting my name out there in this international show is a true honor!  

POSITIVE POLLY SAYS WITH A SMILE: Anything in-between 2 or 3 paintings or (dreaming bigger!) even above my goal (fingers, arms, legs and toes crossed) it will go to purchasing paint, canvas, supplies and the ‘likewise’ to continue future SPLITS ART performances...and yes, of course you are invited!  

BUT WAIT!  THERE’S MORE THAN JUST A GOOD DOES OF KARMA!:  Check out the right hand side of the page... you get a little special something with each level of donation. Plus my ever-enduring gratitude and knowing that there is a smile on my face and likely a smudge of paint on my chin or nose too! *** Please pay via PayPal if possible (*see fine print below) 

IN CLOSING with LOVE, LIGHT and PAINT: 
“All children are artists. The problem is how to remain an artist once he grows up.” - Pablo PicassoAlways Smiling,Erin "SPLITS ART" BarylskiSPECIAL THANKS: My ever-supportive parents Joanne and Brian who couldn't be prouder of their little girl, Loft 954 Studios - you have always given me the space and time I needed to grow SPLITS ART, Chris "Headshots" Hedlund, Josh Ott Photo and Design, RAWartists.org, MadFlower Creative Group, LMNT Gallery, Nina Torres Fine Art Gallery, TSL Lounge, The Stage, Carousel Gallery, Miaimee Makeup, The Beach Channel, ECOMB, Yelp Miami and The Coral Gables Museum, Koncept Events, my 9-5 job Weatherby Healthcare (for allowing me the time off to follow my BHAG!), PS Yoga Studio, Barkan Method Yoga Studio, The New Times, The Pride Center, The Late Show with David Letterman, America's Got Talent, Home Depot, JoAnn Fabrics, Pearl Arts and Crafts Store, Wix.com, my amazing family, my awesome friends and all my super SPLITS ART FANS!!  I love you all!THE FINE PRINT:*Please pay via PayPal if possible!   My first payment for this event due on September 5, 2014 and I need your help to make this happen.  Paying via PayPal puts the money directly into my account, for instant access.  *If you pay via credit card, I am still very grateful, but I will not receive the money until 15 days after my campaign ends.  This will make it extremely difficult for me to make my 2nd payment which is due on September 25th, 2014.*Indiegogo's fees:  When I make my goal, Indiegogo, will deduct 4%, at $15,000 that would be -$600's in fees.  Campaigns that do not make their goal will be deducted 9% of the donations acquired (for me that would be at max apx $1200 in fees).*Please let me know if you have any questions by emailing me at splitsart@gmail.com or visit my website www.splitsart.com MERCI BEAUCOUP!!!

story:
Pre & Post: A Message to My Pre-Digital Self  is an art exhibition that allows our guests to find a linkage between their childhood and present day self via the strong usage of digital media. It is an evening to reflect on our lifestyle before indulging in technology, social media, and more. We want to explore how new forms of digitization affect us today through the visual and digital arts.

Our Mission:

To explore the possibilities of the digital arts by producing an interactive art experience that allows us to reflect on our everyday use of technology and connect our past and present.

Our Vision:

To empower visual and media art students and the Greater Toronto Area communities to acknowledge and appreciate new forms of contemporary art including digital art practices. We hope that people across multiple disciplines will become culturally aware of what the visual and media arts community can bring to society.

Our Aim:

Our goal is to raise $800 in the next three weeks to ensure we can pay our artists righteously, pay for our venue, and have the funds to administer our project. The magnitude of your contribution of any amount will help us deliver an outstanding event and to celebrate digital and contemporary art in the Toronto community.

What Impact Will You Bring to Us?

By supporting us you are not only helping the Arts Management graduating class at the University of Toronto Scarborough to reach their artistic and financial goals. You are also helping the arts community by supporting new initiatives that promote the importance of arts and culture in the GTA. This is not just an opportunity for us to realize our objectives but also a way for us to contribute back to the arts community in Scarborough and the Greater Toronto Area by exhibiting artworks by emerging artists and artists in the region. And by supporting us, you are also contributing to the Toronto arts and cultural communities!

How to Support Us:

Donate at the amount you believe will help contribute to our project. Other ways that you can help support us include following our social media and sharing our project goals with your friends and family.

Website | Facebook | Instagram | Eventbrite

We appreciate your generosity to help fund our capstone project.

For general inquiries and further information, contact us at preandpostart@gmail.com.

story:
What is MAMI?

MAMI is a visual art exhibition and program series curated by Dyani Douze and Ali Rosa-Salas, to be presented at New York City’s Knockdown Center from August 6 to September 5, 2016.

MAMI is an offering to Mami Wata, a pantheon of water deities that originates from West and Central African matriarchal spiritual systems. Commonly portrayed as a singular part-woman/part-aquatic creature, Mami Wata is called upon by those pursuing wealth, wisdom, emotional guidance, sexual liberation, and more. At once beautiful, jealous, generous, and unpredictable, Mami Wata is the embodiment of contradiction and hybridity. Informed by Mami Wata’s mystifying multiplicity, installations by Salome Asega, Nona Faustine, Doreen Garner, Aya Rodriguez-Izumi, MALAXA, and Rodan Tekle reflect on the process of discovering the Others within ourselves.

MAMI Programming

In addition to a series of installations that will transform Knockdown Center's arresting raw architecture, we have also programmed an exciting line-up of events that will keep you coming back to Knockdown Center:

  • Opening Party | August 6, 2016: Celebrate the opening of MAMI with exhibiting artists and curators, hosted by KUNQ, featuring DJ set by  SHYB0I. 

  • MAMI Market | August 13, 2016:  Spend the day at Knockdown Center supporting local designer and artist vendors, along with DJs, performances, workshops and more, co-curated by BALTI GURLS, Browntourage, Smart Girl Club, Top Rank Magazine, POWRPLNT, and more!

  • Performance Lecture | August 20, 2016: Multimedia artists Salome Asega and Dyani Douze join forces with world champion Floyd Little Double Dutch Team for a performance that incorporates light, sound, and of course, double dutch. 

  • Closing Party | September 3, 2016: Spend Labor Day Weekend at Knockdown Center for MAMI's closing party,  a day-to-night Caribbean-themed fete hosted by FAKE ACCENT. Featuring sets by an incredible line-up of womxn-identified DJs like Mursi Layne and TYGAPAW, and a live performance by Princess Nokia!

The Philosophy of 

  For

Us

By

Us

 and YOU

MAMI is an actualization of what we call the Philosophy of FUBU: For Us, By Us.

We have already received the invaluable support from Knockdown Center by way of access to their incredible space and funding for the execution of the visual art installations.

MAMI needs your support in order to be fully realized on the programming end. Together, we intend to support the cost of:

Installation materials 

Performing artist honorariums 

Equipment rental costs 

High-resolution documentation of MAMI installations and programming 

With your support, you are demonstrating your commitment to the work of dynamic early-career womxn-identified artists of African Descent who are shifting paradigms in the contemporary art world and beyond.

As a big hug to you for your support, we have a series of offerings that we are delighted to share with you, made with love by artists we admire. Some highlights include:

Image: Sam Clarke

An exclusive HAT_LINE "MAMI" Hat, just in time for summer.


A very special compilation of mixes by some of the most influential womxn/femme-indentified DJs and producers today, created especially for MAMI, brought to you by NON WORLDWIDE.


An 11'' x 17" poster featuring a still from new media artist Tabita Rezaire's latest video work, SUGARWALLS TEARDOM (2016).

MAMI's Impact 

What MAMI Is Here For: MAMI is an intentional platform to present and support the work of early-career womxn artists of African descent. MAMI is an insistence that womxn of color are not a monolith, and that we can peacefully exist among our many subjectivities.  

What MAMI Isn't Here For: MAMI isn't yet another space to project respectability politics on womxn of color's identities, creative practices, and ways of being.

Risks & Challenges

The artists are committed. The one-of-a kind venue is secured. The dates are confirmed. 

Our community is rich with people like YOU, who like us, are deep believers in the  Philosophy of FUBU. Together, we will manifest MAMI and make it an experience we will all cherish for years to come. 

There is no risk in believing in our collective power!

Other Ways to Show MAMI Love

Every dollar and cent in the MAMI bank is a blessing. 

If you are unable contribute with a pledge,  you can still be of the MAMI family.

1. Get excited about the exhibition! Please share MAMI with your friends and family and help us spread the word. Follow us on Instagram @MAMI_KDC.

2. Collaborate with us! Are you a production manager? Interested in being an exhibition docent? Are you a photographer, videographer, or writer? If you have ideas on how you can join the team, please say hello at DNAHERE[at]gmail[DOT]com.  We'd love to hear from you!

We can’t wait to see you in August!

Love, 

Ali + Dyani

story:
Summary

My name is Dan Mark.  I am a poet, performance artist, musician and all around pursuer of creativity.  "Mourning 'till Morning" is my first fully fleshed out poetry book.  It explores my journey through the darkness of loss and grief and into the dawning at the other side of night. 
This tale is also augmented through the lens of several visual artists who have interpreted my poems through various visual mediums. This is very exciting to me, not only because I love and respect the works of my peers, but also because I get to see my work through the filters of the minds of other artists.  It is wonderful to see their original works bring life to my poems!
This project is important to me because it is the next step in making my art WORK.  If I can get this book into the hands of people around the world (as I intend to) it will help them through their own processes of grief, and perhaps even inspire them to allow the muse to flow through their own hearts.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is how the funding breaks down:
  • Printing: 200 books
  • Color: 7.12$ per book for a total of 1,424$
  • Black and White: 4.54$ per book for a total of 908$
  • If we fund to 1000$ the books will be in Black and White, if we get up to 1500$ they will be in full color (which would be wonderful considering the original art)
  • Anything above 1500 will be split among the artist who contributed to this project!
Here are the perks of donating!
  • Each contributing artist will recieve a copy of the book
  • Each donation over 15$ will recieve a copy of the book (I will be selling them for 20$ after the campaign)
  • Donations over 50$ will receive the book as well as a personal letter of thanks
  • Donations over 100$ will recieve the book with a personalized poem written on the inside cover

The Impact

This book will be a huge personal achievement for me.  Your contribution will help me to create my first professional collection of poems as well as to vindicate the artists who poured their souls into bringing these poems into visual form.

Your contribution will bridge the gap of thought into action with my art.  That is to say, you will turn this collection of thoughts into a physical manifestation; a tool for those who are struggling with their own grief. 

Risks & Challenges

Most of the hurdles have already been jumped in this process.  The book is written and edited, the printing costs have been analysed, and we have about half of the poems illustrated. 

My two largest challenges are

1) Finishing the illustration

2) Funding the printing

I am confident that these hurdles can also be jumped! (with your loving assistance of course) If I don't meet the funding goal, I will use the moneys collected to print whatever manifestation I can.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially to the project, consider sharing it on your social media pages!

If you are a visual artist and would like to contribute to the illustration of the book, please contact me at mark0608@umn.edu
story_txt:
Summary
My name is Dan Mark.  I am a poet, performance artist, musician and all around pursuer of creativity.  "Mourning 'till Morning" is my first fully fleshed out poetry book.  It explores my journey through the darkness of loss and grief and into the dawning at the other side of night. 
This tale is also augmented through the lens of several visual artists who have interpreted my poems through various visual mediums. This is very exciting to me, not only because I love and respect the works of my peers, but also because I get to see my work through the filters of the minds of other artists.  It is wonderful to see their original works bring life to my poems!
This project is important to me because it is the next step in making my art WORK.  If I can get this book into the hands of people around the world (as I intend to) it will help them through their own processes of grief, and perhaps even inspire them to allow the muse to flow through their own hearts.   What We Need & What You Get
Here is how the funding breaks down: 
Printing: 200 books
Color: 7.12$ per book for a total of 1,424$ Black and White: 4.54$ per book for a total of 908$
If we fund to 1000$ the books will be in Black and White, if we get up to 1500$ they will be in full color (which would be wonderful considering the original art)
Anything above 1500 will be split among the artist who contributed to this project! 
Here are the perks of donating!

Each contributing artist will recieve a copy of the book
Each donation over 15$ will recieve a copy of the book (I will be selling them for 20$ after the campaign)
Donations over 50$ will receive the book as well as a personal letter of thanks
Donations over 100$ will recieve the book with a personalized poem written on the inside cover
   The Impact This book will be a huge personal achievement for me.  Your contribution will help me to create my first professional collection of poems as well as to vindicate the artists who poured their souls into bringing these poems into visual form.
Your contribution will bridge the gap of thought into action with my art.  That is to say, you will turn this collection of thoughts into a physical manifestation; a tool for those who are struggling with their own grief. 
    Risks & Challenges Most of the hurdles have already been jumped in this process.  The book is written and edited, the printing costs have been analysed, and we have about half of the poems illustrated. 
My two largest challenges are
1) Finishing the illustration
2) Funding the printing
I am confident that these hurdles can also be jumped! (with your loving assistance of course) If I don't meet the funding goal, I will use the moneys collected to print whatever manifestation I can.
    Other Ways You Can Help If you cannot contribute financially to the project, consider sharing it on your social media pages!
If you are a visual artist and would like to contribute to the illustration of the book, please contact me at mark0608@umn.edu

story:
Short Summary

If you're seeing this campaign, chances are you know us. You may be familiar with Sara from her prolific car-spotting Instagram account, or know Drew from her extensive documentation of the Richmond live music scene. Or maybe you've hung out with us IRL... you know, because we're related to you, or you're in a band with one of us, or something. 

At the end of last summer, after a very trying time in both of our lives, which left both of us unsure of what was to come next, we discovered each other on OKCupid, of all places. Two days later, we met for tacos and Drew Barrymore movies, a first date which ended up lasting 18 hours. It wasn't long before we were madly in love. These days, we share a room, a teddy bear, and a whole bunch of pizza life together. Neither of us are rich, but we have big plans for our future, now that we've found each other.

The two of us share passions for many things, among them history, road trips, forgotten Americana, and automobiles of all shapes and sizes. Though initially inspired by necessity (more on that in a minute), a cross-country road trip would be our absolute dream honeymoon. This may be the only opportunity we have to do things like ascend Pike's Peak, explore the remnants of the legendary Route 66, and stand on a corner in Winslow, Arizona. We're trying to make the most of it.

At this point in our lives, neither of us has that much money to spare. But we do have a ton of creative energy at our disposal. We know we're in a position to need help funding our wedding/honeymoon, but the last thing we want to do is get something for nothing. Therefore, we're prepared to offer a variety of entertaining documentations of our trip to you as a token of our appreciation for your support. Hopefully they will keep you amused as well!

What We Need & What You Get

The initial idea for this trip came from our acquisition of a Jeep Cherokee that has, until now, belonged to Sara's dear friend Mark. Sara's a delivery driver, and currently logs around 180 miles a day driving her manual-transmission Volkswagen. Over the past few months, she's developed some severe pains in her right elbow from the constant shifting of gears. It's basically the delivery-driver version of tennis elbow. The Jeep would provide relief, due to its automatic transmission. Not only that, with her Volkswagen showing more wear by the day, a vehicle in more proper working order is going to be needed before too much longer.

So here's the thing: Mark moved to Seattle about six months ago. The Jeep is with him in the Pacific Northwest. If we're going to take delivery on it, we have to go to where it is. And around the same time this whole Jeep situation came up, the two of us decided that we were so in love, we never wanted to be apart. We'd been joking for months about getting married at the Taco Bell chapel in Vegas. Now, the opportunity was upon us to make that a reality, and join together forever under the auspices of the tacos that we love so much.

We've been saving up some cash for the past few months to make all of this happen, and so far, we've covered our airfare to Seattle. However, the trip home is going to require more funds than we can realistically come up with on our own in a reasonable time frame. (i.e. before the Hallmark busy season hits again and Drew can't leave town for more than two days at a time!) 

We plan to do this trip on the cheap. To jam econo, as D. and Watt would say. We'll probably eat a whole lot of Taco Bell and cheap pizza slices, sleep in the cheapest rooms we can find, visit free and next-to-free tourist attractions, and spend most of our money on gas. We expect the trip to take 7 to 10 days, from when we fly out of Richmond to when we'll drive back into town. We have a place to stay while we're in Seattle (thanks Mark!), but once we depart, after a night or two, we'll be on our own. Ideally, we'd like to raise about $1800 to cover travel expenses and have some emergency funds in case of a breakdown.

We're going to give you something back for your contribution, though! Everyone who pledges a minimum of $5 will be subscribed to our trip-centric email newsletter, and those of you on Facebook will be added to a private Facebook group. The newsletter will go out at the end of each day (ideally), and will collect journal entries, photographs, and other various impressions of each leg of our trip. The facebook group may very well be updated multiple times an hour, if our social media habits are an accurate guide. Both should help you enjoy the journey with us, even if you can't be there to share our sketchy hotel rooms with us.

For those who contribute a minimum of $20, we'll be combining the best words and images from our trip into a publication we're informally calling "Drew & Sara's Wedding Album," which will be brought to you in the form of a black and white photocopied zine! This will help preserve our dorkiness in a more permanent form, since the internet will probably all be behind a Zuckerberg-controlled paywall in another five years or so. (Sara is skeptical of this claim.)

If you really want to pitch in and help out, we've got some more perks available for those with deeper pockets. For anyone who donates $50 or more, we'll not only provide all of the aforementioned rewards but also include a matched pair of mix CDs containing road trip playlists prepared by each of us. Drew's mix will no doubt feature the sort of detailed liner notes that she normally babbles excitedly into Sara's ear when they drive around listening to music. Sara makes no such grandiose promises, but the cover of her mix will be cool, and she's sure to introduce you to some stuff you've never heard before.

Finally, if you really wanna go nuts, kick down $100 or more and Sara and Drew will take you out for pizza. You'll have to either catch us at one of the stops on the trip or, more ideally, hang with us in Richmond after we're home and working again, but we pride ourselves on knowing where the best pizza can be found, so you're gonna eat well. And also, we like to think we're pretty fun to hang with. (Chances are, if you're willing to fork over $100, you think so too.)

Risks & Challenges

If you're worried about us coming through, keep in mind that Drew has been cranking out a weekly internet column about live music for three or more years now, and has been producing physical zines semi-regularly since 1991 (when she was 15 years old). Also, Sara's photographic eye is impeccable, and she pretty much can't help taking tons of photos all the time. Finally, Drew does a lot better at meeting goals and staying on task with Sara around to support and encourage her, so chances are these two will push each other to get this done fast and well. After all, we're even more excited about this than you probably are!

We've outlined our ideal trip (shown in the cover image above), and we'd like to take the trip in the last half of August, in order to make it work best with our job schedules. If we aren't able to raise enough cash to make the ideal plan work, we may have to change our itinerary or timeframe slightly. However, this is a trip we pretty much have to make by the end of this summer, and I assure you we will be married by the time it's all said and done. There will be some form of trip, and some form of wedding, to document. And document it we will! But it's only with your support that we can do this in the awesomest manner possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that plenty of you are as broke as we are and are no more able to fund our wedding than we are. However, if you support what we're trying to do, you can still help! Share the link to this campaign on your social media if you are into lesbians taking cross-country Jeep trips. It'll be like Thelma And Louise, except instead of driving off a cliff at the end, we'll drive home to live happily ever after.

story:
The Inspiration – Dating In The Modern World:

We go through a lot to meet people today. I mean really
meet people. It takes enormous efforts these days to make it past
the filters of online dating profiles, text messages, hear-say and
chance-meetings – to get to the point where we actually listen to
one another and learn what we’re all about. I say, “enough!”


Who Am I?

My name is Leah Devora and I am  an artist who has worked in New York, L.A., San Francisco, Atlanta and Chicago with all types of media for over 20 years. I’ve painted with heavily textured oils & acrylics … to tar & roofing cement for sculpture … printed t-shirts and create usable art in the form of book covers, iPad cases & hand bags as well.

You may have even seen some of my work and not known it on the sets of HBO’s Entourage, Six Feet Under or West Wing. And if you are a moviegoer you can currently find my work papering the walls as murals for the growing iPic Movie Theater chain across the country. I’m always looking to grow and challenge myself as an artist – and that is what led me to The Dating Project – Voices.

 

The Process

I have been recording men and women speaking about what they are looking for in a partner, their deal breakers, must haves ... their wants and desires. The goal is to create an art experience for people to actually hear what we are saying about ourselves and to each other from a whole new angle. Do we realized what we are putting out there about ourselves and others? Is our quest for the "perfect mate" realistic? Is it a fantasy? Is it absurd? Sometimes it’s best to rethink it to get those answers and attain better result.

For Love & Money – Where does your donation go?

•  10% of my funds will go towards charitable causes such as Free Arts For Abused Children and Bark Avenue Animal Rescue.

•  The art space rental – A significant amount will go
toward this and the staff running it.

•  Sound equipment – Another chunk will be going
towards buying speakers and microphones

•  Lighting – This is a crucial element to set the mood of
each room (bulbs, stands and timers).

•  Computers & Hard Drives – All of the recording is being
done with Garageband on the Mac so there will be a
need for multiple computers set up around the gallery.
We have our personal Macs, but need more space
and storage.

•  Promotion – A major promotional effort with an outside
company is being put in motion for this project
reaching out to lifestyle magazines, blogs, TV/cable
interviews and more.

For a full body of my work, please also visit www.leahdevora.com. Thanks for visiting and your potential support of this exciting project!
